etymology.value: From Latin *in-* (intensive prefix) + *anire* (to blow, breathe), related to *anima* (breath, soul).

verb_forms.present_indicative: inanio, inanis, inanit, inanimus, inanitis, inaniunt
verb_forms.imperfect_indicative: inaniebam, inaniebas, inaniebat, inaniebamus, inaniebatis, inaniebant
verb_forms.future_indicative: inaniam, inanies, inaniet, inaniemus, inanietis, inanient
verb_forms.perfect_indicative: inanivi, inanivisti, inanivit, inanivimus, inanivistis, inaniverunt
verb_forms.pluperfect_indicative: inaniveram, inaniveras, inaniverat, inaniveramus, inaniveratis, inaniverant
verb_forms.future_perfect_indicative: inanivero, inaniveris, inaniverit, inaniverimus, inaniveritis, inaniverint
verb_forms.present_subjunctive: inaniem, inanies, inaniet, inaniemus, inanietis, inanient
verb_forms.imperfect_subjunctive: inanirem, inanires, inaniret, inaniremus, inaniretis, inanirent
verb_forms.perfect_subjunctive: inaniverim, inaniveris, inaniverit, inaniverimus, inaniveritis, inaniverint
verb_forms.pluperfect_subjunctive: inanivissem, inanivisses, inanivisset, inanivissemus, inanivissetis, inanivissent

usage_notes.explanation: In Latin, *inanire* means to empty, exhaust, or make void. It is derived from *in-* (intensive prefix) and *anire* (to blow, breathe), related to *anima* (breath, soul). It is mostly found in classical Latin texts.

readability_explanation.text: This is a Latin word, so readability is only applicable to those studying Latin.
